newsitem.title: USA: Two Jordanians convicted in U.S. elude authorities.
newsitem.headline: Two Jordanians convicted in U.S. elude authorities.

text.p: - A Jordanian brother and sister convicted of bank fraud in the United States have become fugitives, the FBI said on Friday.
A second brother convicted in the case was arrested on Thursday as he tried to leave the country, the FBI said. A third did not take part in the plot, it added.
Tony Houran of Old Tappan, New Jersey, also known as Aktham Abuhouran, was arrested before he could board a flight at New York's Kennedy International Airport on Thursday night, the FBI said.

But his sister and one of his brothers -- Adma Houran of Old Tappan and Adam or Adham Houran of Saddle River, New Jersey -- eluded Port Authority police at the airport and were still at large, the FBI said.

Tony and Adam Houran were facing sentencing in a federal court in Philadelphia on Wednesday. Adma Houran was serving a sentence of four months of house arrest. The FBI identified all three as Jordanian nationals.
Hitham or Steve Houran, serving a sentence for the same crime, did not join his brothers' and sister's dash to the airport, the FBI said.

Port Authority police had been on the lookout for the three Hourans after the FBI received a signal when Tony and Adam cut their electronic monitoring bracelets, the FBI said. Adma also cut her monitoring device and joined them, it said.

The four siblings were convicted of breaking federal banking laws in the 1992 collapse of the Bank of Brandywine Valley in West Chester, Pennsylvania, a Philadelphia suburb. They borrowed nearly $7 million to help prop up the family's failing construction business.
